... Your explanation of why you'd lay down in a falling elevator is way off.

Your explanation is approaching this like there is no cushion and your dealing with an impact as if the elevator was dropped from a crane. In this case the fact that you're in a box does nothing to change physics; there is little difference to your body hitting that concrete directly.

The suggestion to lay down in an elevator is assuming there is in fact a cession of air and cable. It assumes the deceleration at the bottom is already survivable. What you're doing by laying down is transferring the inertia of your insides to the floor thru as little tissue as possible, thus avoiding secondary injuries (broken knee or herniated spinal disk, for example)

Why would you want to spread the impact out? Wouldn't it be best to stand in a corner, that way your legs take the impact, leaving them broken and injured, but your internal organs fine and not as jumbled up. That's what's recommended for if your parachute doesn't deploy properly when skydiving. Take it all in your legs, so your upper body, the part with all the important bits, doesn't have to take as much, and the shock of hitting the ground (the wave that'll go through your body) won't rupture anything important. If the elevator falls, it's likely to cause som attention and bring people to call 911 rather quickly, if they're not already on the way for some other disaster, in which the elevator will be checked for any stuck persons.

The breaks on the machine are only made to hold the elevator in place. They will not slow down or stop a falling unit. The safeties or breaks under the car are the only thing that will slow it down to a stop. If the power fails and the unit is in flight the machine breaks will drop and burn out very fast and do very little if anything at all. As long as the cable to the brakes under the car is in place and the tripping device is set up correctly then the car will stop.

Why on earth would lying flat against the floor improve the situation? Your body would have to come to a stop from the same speed in the same amount of time, therefore the acceleration (which is what would kill you) is not changed. Surley a MUCH better way would be to just stand upright with knees slightly bent - the body is designed to absorb force in an upright position and the compression of your knees and spine, along with the likely breakage of a few bones would slow the impact from your brain's perspective - leading to a much lower acceleration. People who 'free run' and jump off buildings land on their feet and roll after high jumps, they don't bellyflop onto the floor. I struggle to see why this method has any credibility and I challenge anyone to explain the principals behind it and why it would be better than the method I just highlighted

Couple of things to point out. If the elevator starts moving in upward direction most of the new elevators will have what we call rope gripper or secondary brakes. This rope gripper is basically jaw which will gently grab the cables and stop the upward elevator movement (or the secondary brake). Some of the gear less elevators have two primary and two secondary brakes. Also every elevator has at the bottom of the pit buffers which are designed to stop and soften the elevator hitting the floor at full speed of the elevator.

Does laying flat really make sense? The most important organs are your heart and your brain. If you're standing, it would take longer for the shock of impact to reach your heart and brain and large portions of it would be absorbed by your lower body by the time it reaches. If you're flat, the impact is more evenly distributed but greater on your upper body compared to the previous scenario.

Shouldn't you squat and bend your legs instead of lying on the floor? If you lie on the floor, then the impact is distributed evenly on all body parts (vital and non vital), i.e. your head takes the same impact as your legs. If you concentrate the impact on your bended legs, and let them crumple, the peak force is much lower. This is why cars deform so much in a crash.

Nice video.  Falling elevators are something you only see in the movies.  I suggest anyone who watched THIS video, search for a documentary called 'Trapped In An Elevator' - it's a NOVA documentary, and they cover the whole dropping elevator thing very well.  It's strange how so many people are convinced that a dropping elevator can happen at all.  Very early elevators are probably responsible for that belief, but anything from about 1950 onwards have very good brakes and safety interlocks to hold the cabin in the shaft.  Even so-called 'Stuck' elevators are not really stuck per-se', they are just not responding to the controller or PLU - usually cos the controller/PLU is not getting the correct response from one or more shaft and cabin sensors.  They are really very, very safe - you are more likely to be involved in a car accident then ever be in a dropping elevator.

Probably should mention that it's extremely dangerous to try to pry open the doors to escape, especially if you are stuck between floors. Elevators can and do suddenly move a little bit when they are stuck. When I was a student at Ohio State, an overloaded elevator in a dorm suddenly stopped between floors, and a student was crushed to death when he decided to try to escape by prying open the door and crawling to what he believed was safety, but the elevator suddenly shifted (because it was overloaded and things were going wrong already). The fail-safe systems DID work, but that didn't help him because they just prevent falling, not sudden shifting. General safety protocol is to wait for help to arrive; he would have been safe, along with everyone else in the elevator, if he had patiently waited for help to handle the elevator situation from the outside after calling for assistance. Also, don't put more people in an elevator than it's rated for!

BOOSTER SHOTS: Oddities, musings and news from the
health world Are elevators really hazardous to your health?December 15,
2011|By Karen Kaplan, Los Angeles Times/For the Booster Shots blog

“U.S. elevators make 18 billion passenger trips per year.” Those trips
result in about 27 deaths annually, according to estimates from the U.S.
Bureau of Labor Statistics and the Consumer Product Safety Commission.
That works out to a fatality rate of 0.00000015% per trip. Injuries and
deaths are so uncommon that there isn’t much written about them in the
medical literature.

A 2009 report in Occupational Health and Safety notes that people who
install and maintain elevators may become injured in a variety of ways,
including, “falls, electrical shocks, muscle strains and other injuries related to
lockout/tagout, confined spaces, scaffolds, cranes, rigging, hoisting
and heavy equipment.” The safety profile for passengers is much
better. “Because of the intricate, redundant and regulated safety
features built in to every elevator, catastrophes are rare outside of
movies and TV,” according to the report. So-called rope elevators
require only one woven steel cable, but they usually have four to eight
cables just in case. In addition, elevators are equipped with “automatic
braking systems” that are backed up by “electromagnetic brakes.”
Finally, the report notes, “at the bottom of the shaft is a heavy-duty
shock absorber system designed to save passengers if all else fails.”
